item.title: Elden Ring Nightreign: Hardest Nightlords Tier List
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Augur
  • Tricephalos
  • Sentient Pest
  • Gaping Jaw
  • Fissure in the Fog
  • Equilibrious Beast
  • The Night Aspect
  • Darkdrift Knight

There are eight Nightlords in Elden Ring Nightreign , but you are not able to challenge the final boss until you have completed at least four of the previous seven expeditions. Some of the hardest expeditions in Nightreign will take you several attempts to complete, but even the less difficult Nightlords present a significant challenge for unprepared players.

After you defeat the Tricephalos expedition, the only required expedition in Nightreign , you will be able to access six more expeditions to fulfill the requirements to face the Night Aspect. This hardest Nightlords in Nightreign tier list ranks every Nightlord based on the complexity of each boss' moveset, how much each weakness affects each Nightlord, and how difficult each boss is to beat even under the best of circumstances.

8 Augur

Maris, Fathom of Night

  • Weakness : Lightning

The Augur expedition is one of the easiest expeditions to complete, depending on your Nightreign comp. If your party is full of melee-oriented characters, you'll have a hard time hitting the boss while it's in the air, and you'll have a hard time catching up to Maria as it floats around the arena.

However, a party with at least two ranged characters will find Augur to be laughably easy, especially if you can find Bows or spells with the Lightning affinity to take advantage of the Augur weakness. Brince along an Ironeye and a Recluse – or try an all-Ironeye comp – to keep the damage up and dissipate this ethereal Nightlord without too many problems.

The boss does have some powerful moves, but no instant kills, and most of its strongest abilities are easy to avoid by Surge Sprinting away or with a well-timed dodge.

7 Tricephalos

Gladius, Beast of Night

  • Weakness : Holy

Gladius is the first Nightlord Nightreign players must beat to access the rest of the Nightlord expeditions. But despite being the first (and only mandatory) boss, the Tricephalos expedition is not the easiest expedition in the game. This is because of the Gladius phase transition when it splits into three different enemies for a short time, its speed and ability to cover ground quickly, and its long-range fire breath and chain attacks.

Gladius is not particularly weak to any one type of playstyle, unlike Augur which is made much easier with ranged party members. But if you can split up the dogs between all three players when the boss separates so they don't focus you down one by one, and if you can get some Holy weapons to stagger the boss (and its split forms) and interrupt its most powerful moves, you shouldn't have too much trouble with the Tricephalos.

6 Sentient Pest

Gnoster, Wisdom of Night

  • Weakness : Fire

The Sentient Pest is essentially a duo boss. This Nightlord is where things start to ramp up a bit in difficulty as you must split your attention between both the flying Moth boss and the gigantic Grub. When the Grub boss hardens, you must attack the Moth. When the Grub's shell dissipates, you must swap back.

Both bosses have a slew of moves that can kill players caught unawares quickly – think of this difficult Nightreign duo boss fight as a mix of the Moonlight Butterfly from Dark Souls 1 and the Magma Wyrm from Elden Ring . The Moth casts ranged projectile magic attacks, while the Grub deals huge physical damage and spreads Poison at close range.

However, if you can get a source of Fire damage, you can melt both boss' HP bars as hitting either enemy with Fire creates a damage-over-time effect unique to this Nightlord.

5 Gaping Jaw

Adel, Baron of Night

  • Weakness : Poison

The Gaping Jaw is where things really start to ramp up, and your skills as a player and knowledge of the boss's moveset starts to come into play. The Gaping Jaw boss is one of the hardest Nightreign bosses, at least compared to the previous three on this list, because it moves around the arena extremely fast, deals massive damage with both its unpredictable grab and close-range AoE attacks, and long-range lightning attacks.

The first time you face this boss, spend time to memorize its moveset and the timing to dodge its grab and close-range melee attacks. In addition to learning the timing to dodge Adel's attacks, you should bring a source of Poison into the fight, whether that be a Poison affinity weapon or a spell that inflicts Poison, like Poison Mist.

When the Gaping Jaw is Poisoned, it will be interrupted, reel back, and throw up its guts to get rid of the poisoning. This effect cannot be triggered constantly, but when you do inflict Poison, get ready to wail on the boss uninhibited for a solid five or six seconds as it pukes.

Additionally, Frostbite will slow down Adel after the damage procs. This effect is not as pronounced as the Poison effect on the Gaping Jaw, but it can help make the boss' rapid moveset much easier to deal with.

4 Fissure in the Fog

Caligo, Miasma of Night

  • Weakness : Fire

The Fissure in the Fog is one of the hardest bosses in Nightreign and, like Libra, requires a fair bit of mechanical knowledge to succeed. The boss deals Frostbite damage with most of its attacks, breathes Frostbite across the battlefield regularly, and has an attack that can outright kill all but the most defensive characters at the maximum level instantly.

You must get behind special ice pillars to avoid being killed by this attack, which is always preceded by an arena-blanketing fog.

Caligo's weakness is Fire, and like the Sentient Pest, hitting the boss with a Fire attack will impart a damage-over-time effect. This isn't as impactful as some other boss weaknesses in Nightreign , but it's still useful to try to get a source of Fire damage to keep your DPS up during this long fight.

3 Equilibrious Beast

Libra, Creature of Night

  • Weakness : Madness

The first five bosses in the full expedition list can be tough, but if you go in with the right weaknesses and strategies in mind, you'll usually perform pretty well. That all changes with the Equilibrious Beast, the first of the hardest Nightlord bosses in Nightreign that take some serious prep and knowledge to beat.

For starters, the boss' weakness is Madness, which is already pretty hard to come across in a normal playthrough. Look for the Frenzy Eye symbol on points of interest on your map to find Madness weapons. But Madness alone won't save you in this fight, even though it does help control the boss – you need to know its mechanics, especially the Sigil mechanic, and you need to make a smart choice when Libra offers you a deal at the start of the fight.

  • At the start of the fight, Libra will offer you a choice between three or four different effects, most of which have a trade-off in exchange for a boon.
    • In most situations, it's best to ignore this deal and just smack the boss to start the fight, giving you and your team a few seconds to deal damage before the boss starts to fight back.

  • The most important thing in this fight, aside from learning how to avoid its most damaging normal moves, is the Sigil mechanic. When the boss reaches certain HP thresholds, it will begin to meditate and summon Sigils around the boss arena.
    • You must destroy all of these Sigils as fast as possible, but some of them are high above the ground where no melee character can reach.
    • For this reason, it is essential to bring at least one (preferably two) ranged characters into this fight to deal with this mechanic efficiently.

  • When the boss inflicts Madness on everyone and drops shards around the arena, you must quickly sprint between shards to prevent Madness buildup from triggering a damage burst

If you don't destroy every Sigil, the boss will gain a new Enraged moveset and deal significantly more damage temporarily.

2 The Night Aspect

Heolstor, The Nightlord

  • Weakness : Holy

The final boss of the game is one of the hardest Nightlords to beat in Nightreign and offers a significant step up in challenge compared to the Fissure in the Fog and Equilibrious Beast expeditions. Heolstor wields several weapons that players might recognize, including the Moonlight Greatsword, can teleport around the arena on a whim, and has a vast array of attacks that can catch even the most seasoned Elden Ring Nightreign player off guard.

Notably, The Night Aspect is one of the only Nightlords with a full second phase that begins when you reduce the boss' HP bar to 0. His HP bar will refill, and Heolstor will become significantly faster, stronger, and gain new moves. Defeating Heolstor is tricky and it will likely take most players several attempts to get to the second phase, let alone beat the final boss of Nightreign .

But there is a trick – like other bosses, the Night Aspect has a weakness, in this case Holy damage. If you hit Heolstor with enough Holy attacks, the boss will stagger and gain a golden glow. When the golden glow disappears, you can interrupt it again with Holy attacks. Make sure every member of your party has access to Holy damage in some way to make the final boss significantly easier to deal with.

1 Darkdrift Knight

Fulghor, Champion of Nightglow

  • Weakness : Lightning

The Darkdrift Knight is the hardest boss in Elden Ring Nightreign , and the most difficult Nightlord – it's even more difficult than the final boss. This is because it has a long-range charge attack that can be difficult to avoid, arena-covering AoE attacks that are nearly impossible to dodge, and because it's one of the most mobile Nightlords.

Fulghor swiftly sprints around the arena and closes distance quickly with fast stabs and aerial slam attacks. This makes it difficult to land slow attacks and Ultimate Arts to interrupt it.

The boss's weakness is Lightning, and if you are able to acquire a weapon with the Lightning affinity, use it in this fight to more easily interrupt Fulghor. Pay special attention to when the boss stops to begin its AoE attack, which will spawn blades around the arena that slam down for massive damage. If you can stagger the boss as it winds up this attack (which is easier with Lightning weapons) it will cease the AoE attack and go back to its normal rotation.

8 Images
8 Images
Elden Ring Nightreign
9 /10
7.2 /10
Released
May 30, 2025

WHERE TO PLAY

item.title: Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon - All Keeper's Tag Locations (Honor Over Life Achievement/Trophy)
item.description:
In Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon , you'll come across a side quest called "Brothers in Arms," where you need to collect Keeper's Tags from fallen Keepers scattered throughout the world. These tags serve as proof of their sacrifice and must be delivered to Fearghas, the quartermaster at the Horns of the South castle.

While the quest only requires you to find a few tags to complete it, there are 13 Keeper's Tags hidden across the game world. Collecting and delivering all of them will unlock the "Honor Over Life" achievement/trophy.

All Keeper's Tag Locations in Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon

Below, you'll find the location of each Keeper's Tag in Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon . You can pick them up in any order you like, except for the first Keeper's Tag found in Island Asylum.

If you're going for the achievement/trophy, don't turn in the Keeper's Tags one by one. This will cause the quest to end, and Fearghas won't accept the rest of the tags from you, locking you out of the trophy.

Island Asylum/Ninian's Tag (Keeper's Tag 1)

The first Keeper's Tag to unlock the trophy/achievement can be found in Island Asylum, the prologue region of the game, and it's entirely missable. After Caradoc frees you, keep moving forward, defeating the Red Priests and Undead enemies along the way. Eventually, you'll find a locked door requiring the Laboratory Key to get in.

Loot the key from the body of the Red Priest on the bridge nearby and enter the room. Now, kill the enemies and talk to the NPC that they were experimenting on. Agree to kill him and loot the Ninian's Tag from his body afterward.

Near the Starting Area (Keeper's Tag 2)

The second Keeper's Tag can be picked up as soon as you wash up on the shore at the start of Act 1 of Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon . From the beach, head west, and you'll find an abandoned camp with a Corpse Eater enemy. Defeat the monster and loot the nearby corpse to find the second Keeper's Tag.

The Flooded Mine (Keeper's Tag 3 & 4)

The Flooded Mine, located near The Peninsula fast travel point, has two Keeper's Tags that you can collect before you even reach the castle. Head towards the location marked on the map to find the entrance to the Flooded Mine dungeon. The first Keeper's Tag is located beside the entrance.

For the next one, head inside the Flooded Mine. In the area with water, swim across and go through the tunnel on the right. Instead of crossing the bridge, dive into the water and start swimming towards the opening on the left. Keep swimming forward to find a dead Keeper between some rocks underwater. This is where you'll find this Keeper's Tag.

Near a Druidic Shrine on the Beach (Keeper's Tag 5)

Stay on the beach and keep heading west. You'll eventually arrive at an area with two wooden huts and some Redcap monsters. Defeat the monsters and check the huts. There's a dead Keeper in the western hut carrying a Keeper's Tag that you can loot.

Pate's Tag (Keeper's Tag 6)

You'll find Keeper Pate on the northern wall of Horns of the South castle. Talk to him, and he'll ask you to read him a letter. Choose "I'll read it for you." Then, read the Letter from a Keeper's Sister in your inventory and talk to him again.

Tell him the truth about the Letter, and no matter what you choose next, he will jump to his death. Rest at a nearby camp and go outside the castle and check the area under the wall where he was stationed earlier. You'll find his dead body on the ground and can loot it for a Keeper's Tag, along with some other items.

Lighthouse (Keeper's Tag 7)

Head to the second lighthouse at the back of the Horns of the South castle. Once you get to the entrance, go left past the copper ore. You'll find a dead Keeper near a chest, and you can loot the body for a Keeper's Tag.

Sunken Village (Keeper's Tag 8, 9, & 10)

There are three Keeper's Tags in the Sunken Village area located north of Horns of the South. This area is swarming with monsters, so you'll want to be careful while collecting these tags.

Head to the center of the village with the large interconnected wooden houses. Go up the stairs and cross the bridge. Once you cross the bridge, go inside the house on the right and go up to find the first Keeper's Tag for the location. For the next one, go back out and move past the bridge to reach a tower. Turn right immediately after entering the tower to spot another dead Keeper.

For the final Keeper's Tag in this area, go to the fast travel point of the zone. Go to the southern edge of the beach and swim across to the other side. From here, head through the large passage in the ravine to find a dead Keeper at the end, along with an Origin Potion.

King's Road (Keeper's Tag 11)

You'll find a dead Keeper in the open area below King's Road, heading towards Archspire. From the King's Road fast travel point, look for an opening in the wall to go through. Now, look for a large boulder in the area marked on the map to find the next Keeper's Tag.

Gallows (Keeper's Tag 12)

If you've picked up the Bounty for Fingerless Colm, finding this location is easy. Just follow the quest marker and defeat the Bandit Leader located near the East Gate fast travel point. You'll find a dead Keeper in the same area as Fingerless Colm on a wooden platform.

Forgotten Cemetery (Keeper's Tag 13)

Go to the Forgotten Cemetery Crypt and head to the room where you found the Necromancer. On the northern side of the room, you'll find a small opening through the rocks. Jump up the rocks and go through it. Follow the narrow passages, and you'll eventually find a dead Keeper's body on your right in a small opening. You can also drop down from this area after picking up the tag to get outside.

Once you've picked up all the Keeper's Tags, you can talk to Fearghas back at the castle to turn them all in at once. This will complete the Brothers in Arms quest and also unlock the Honor Over Life achievement/trophy in Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon .

6 Images
6 Images

Your comment has not been saved

item.title: Elden Ring Nightreign: Best Characters Tier List
item.description:
Quick Links

  • B- Tier: Guardian
  • B Tier: Duchess
  • B+ Tier: Revenant
  • A- Tier: Wylder
  • A Tier: Raider
  • A+ Tier: Recluse
  • S Tier: Executor
  • S+ Tier: Ironeye

There are eight Nightfarers in Elden Ring Nightreign , each of which comes with a set of unique character abilities, stat scalings, and other strengths that create eight unique playstyles. Though every Nightfarer in the game is perfectly capable of beating every Nightlord, and there is no single worst class in Nightreign , the best classes have high damage, utility, or other benefits that make them worth picking over others.

The best classes in Elden Ring Nightreign can find a home for themselves on any team composition thanks to synergistic abilities, useful party utility skills, or sheer damage output that puts them a head above the rest. This best Nightreign classes tier list ranks each character based on these aspects and explains why every Nightreign class is ranked at its particular place on this list.

8 B- Tier: Guardian

A Great Tank That Lacks Power & Variety

  • Favored Weapon : Halberd
  • Guardian Passive : Steel Guard
  • Guardian Skill : Whirlwind
  • Guardian Ultimate : Wings of Salvation

Guardian is unparalleled as a single-target tank when he can attract enemy attention toward his shield and take advantage of his special Guard Counter when wielding Halberds. His Whirlwind skill is useful for dealing with groups, and Wings of Salvation will revive allies if you land near them and grant a temporary defensive boost.

All of this sounds like a pretty good combination of defensive abilities. But Guardian is one of the worst classes in Nightreign because it's slow, it doesn't do much damage, and other classes can tank just as effectively with the right setup. Plus, you won't be in many one-on-one situations where Guardian's strengths come into play.

Ultimately, there are no bad classes in Nightreign , and if you get certain Relics and master the class, you'll be able to beat any Nightlord. But Raider, Wylder, and Executor all have more damaging and more varied abilities that are useful outside of boss encounters.

7 B Tier: Duchess

Requires Team Coordination To Play Well

  • Favored Weapon : Daggers
  • Duchess Passive : Magnificent Poise
  • Duchess Skill : Restage
  • Duchess Ultimate : Finale

The Duchess is one of the best classes in Nightreign when played well, but a lot of this class' potential depends on your teammates and your ability to effectively communicate. Her Magnificent Poise passive lets her dodge twice in quick succession, which is great for diving in and out of combat, and her Finale Ultimate Art will shroud the whole team in invisibility, allowing you to revive each other or heal up without drawing aggro.

The Duchess' character skill is what gives her the potential to be so strong, but it's also her major weakness. Restage repeats the damage dealt over the last few seconds, and if you can time it directly after both of your allies deal a chunk of damage, you'll shred through HP bars. But if you aren't able to communicate with teammates and don't time it well, it's not nearly as impactful.

6 B+ Tier: Revenant

Low HP, No FP Regeneration – But Summons & Ult Are Great

  • Favored Weapon : None (Sacred Seals)
  • Revenant Passive : Necromancy
  • Revenant Skill : Summon Spirit
  • Revenant Ultimate : Immortal March

Certainly one of the most unique classes in Nightreign , the Revenant can summon three different spirits to aid her in combat, summon the spirit of defeated enemies to her side temporarily, and can imbue her allies (and summons) with temporary invincibility with her Ultimate Art. Her Ultimate is one of the few that can revive allies from a three-bar downed meter, too.

The Revenant has two downsides: her low HP and FP regeneration, and her lack of options if her summons die in a major encounter. While the Recluse can regain FP from gathering Affinity Residue, Revenant has no such ability and must rely entirely on Starlight Shards to refill her FP bar in combat. Her spirits have HP, too, and if they die, it takes some time for them to regenerate enough to become available to summon again.

If you can get a strong Sacred Seal with good Incantations, and are able to find plenty of Starlight Shards to fuel your spells while your summons distract enemies away from you, Revenant can be a huge asset to any team composition.

5 A- Tier: Wylder

A Balanced & Agile Melee All-Rounder

  • Favored Weapon : Greatswords
  • Wylder Passive : Sixth Sense
  • Wylder Skill : Claw Shot
  • Wylder Ultimate : Onslaught Strike

Wylder is the "default" class in Nightreign , and though it's far from the best class in Nightreign , it's certainly not the worst, either. Wylder is a very balanced class that is able to wield any armament effectively, but especially Greatswords which will unlock an alternate weapon moveset exclusive to Wylder.

His Sixth Sense ability will prevent one deadly blow, and his Onslaught Strike Ultimate is one of the few that can interrupt any boss (when charged). Claw Shot is a nice mobility option that can be upgraded to deal Fire damage with an early relic, and is useful for closing the distance to enemies or traversing the open world a bit faster.

Wylder has good melee damage, an easy-to-learn moveset, good mobility, and a useful Ultimate (which can also revive allies), which makes him one of the best starting characters in Nightreign and one of the most balanced classes in general.

4 A Tier: Raider

Has Two Ways To Interrupt & Great Stance Breaking

  • Favored Weapon : Colossal Weapons, Greataxes, Greathammers
  • Raider Passive : Fighter's Resolve
  • Raider Skill : Retaliate
  • Raider Ultimate : Totem Stela

While Wylder can effectively wield just about any melee weapon, Raider is a bit more of a specialist. A colossal man who wields Colossal Weapons, Raider is one of the best classes in Nightreign for two major reasons: he has two abilities that can interrupt bosses easily, and he is the best character for breaking Stance.

Raider's character skill and passive are intertwined – Fighter's Resolve grants extra damage to Retaliate as you take damage and prevents being knocked down while using the skill. The Retaliate skill makers the Raider rear back and headbutt his target, but if you have taken enough damage and are glowing grey, you'll wind up an open-palmed strike that will knock down all but the strongest bosses. His Totem Stela is useful too, especially if you have a Recluse, Revenant, or Ironeye in the party who can take advantage of its height.

3 A+ Tier: Recluse

An Extremely Powerful, But Extremely Complex, Sorceress

  • Favored Weapon : None (Staves and Sacred Seals)
  • Recluse Passive : Elemental Defense
  • Recluse Skill : Magic Cocktail
  • Recluse Ultimate : Soulblood Song

One of the best classes in Nightreign , but also one of its most complex, is the Recluse. This witchy character can effectively use both Staves and Sacred Seals and is, for all intents and purposes, the game's default spellcaster character. Though the class can effectively wield Incantations and Sacred Seals alike, her class skill Magic Cocktail is what makes her complexity and damage ceiling so high.

By absorbing one of four elements from enemies and allies (after they are hit by Magic, Fire, Holy, or Lightning attacks), you will restore a little bit of FP and gain one of three colored sigils. Gather three sigils and you will cast a spell depending on the combination of Affinity Residues you gathered.

There are a total of 14 Magic Cocktail spells, and if you want to master the Recluse, you'll have to know all of these by heart.

Her Ultimate is useful as it marks enemies for a short time, which makes allies' hits recover HP and FP. But the class' main weakness, and the main weakness of all spellcaster builds in Elden Ring , is an extremely low HP pool.

Be careful not to draw boss aggro, and learn every residue combo to take full advantage of Magic Cocktail, and you'll shred through enemy HP bars with a neverending onslaught of spells.

2 S Tier: Executor

Perfect Deflect Mechanics & Unparalleled Status Effects

  • Favored Weapon : Katanas
  • Executor Passive : Tenacity
  • Executor Skill : Cursed Sword
  • Executor Ultimate : Aspect of the Crucible: Beast

The Executor is the best melee class in Nightreign , and one of the best classes in the game in general, for a few major reasons. Most notably, the Executor is the only class in the game with access to a perfect block mechanic. With the Cursed Sword drawn, the Executor can block just before an enemy hit to completely negate HP loss, refund block Stamina, deal Stance damage to the attacker, and break open the Cursed Sword slightly.

The Executor also starts with an S scaling in Arcane and high Dexterity scaling, which makes him the best class for inflicting status effects in the game, especially if you can get two Katanas with different status effects to dual-wield. The Aspects of the Crucible: Beast Ultimate is one of the game's most awesome skills, and when active, you get a whole new moveset with wide swipes, powerful slams, a roar attack, and even a "weapon skill" that lets you slice through enemies with a holy blade.

Executor is not an easy class to play, and you'll have to learn how to wield the Cursed Blade and time perfect blocks right to master it. But when you get the hang of the Executor, you'll be able to face off against any enemy in the game without taking damage.

1 S+ Tier: Ironeye

Low Damage, But It's The Most Reliable Class In Nightreign

  • Favored Weapon : Bows ( not Crossbows/Greatbows)
  • Ironeye Passive : Eagle Eye
  • Ironeye Skill : Marking
  • Ironeye Ultimate : Single Shot

Ironeye is the best class in Nightreign not necessarily because of his damage output, but because of the sheer amount of utility and party synergy he brings to the team. Ironeye is a ranged Bow expert who can stay safely out of range of melee attacks and shoot enemies – or revive teammates – from afar.

His passive ability Eagle Eye increases item rarity for the entire team, which is useful for any team comp, and his Marking skill will mark enemies, which increases damage done to them. When enough damage has been dealt, the mark will shatter and deal an enormous chunk of damage similar to a Bleed proc.

Notably, the dash Ironeye performs when he uses the Marking skill has i-frames for almost its entire animation, making it an exceptional defensive and offensive tool in his kit.

Ironeye's Ultimate ability Single Shot deals an enormous chunk of damage to its target and everything in between Ironeye and his mark. It can go through any terrain and will tear through everything within about a five-meter radius of your Single Shot path. This skill also is one of the few that can interrupt bosses.

Ironeye is an asset to any team he is on, as long as your other teammates can pump out the damage and keep attention away. His ability to easily revive teammates from a distance, his passive item rarity increase, his useful and protective Marking dash, and his interrupting Ultimate make him the most reliable class and best character in Nightreign – even if he can't pump out DPS like some other classes in the game.

8 Images
8 Images
Elden Ring Nightreign
9 /10
7.2 /10
Released
May 30, 2025

WHERE TO PLAY

item.title: Preview: EA Sports College Football 26 is Smartly Building on a Solid Foundation
item.description:
Last year saw the grand return of college football with EA Sports College Football 25 , and as expected, it's following in the footsteps of its older sister Madden NFL as an annualized franchise. CFB 25 was a fantastic game, although imperfect, and EA Sports looks to continue refining it with this year's EA Sports College Football 26 . Sporting Alabama WR Ryan Williams and Ohio State WR Jeremiah Smith on the cover, EA Sports College Football 26 speaks to the passion of football fans and developers alike.

Game Rant recently visited EA in Orlando where we had a brief hands-on preview of EA Sports College Football 26 after a detailed breakdown of all the changes, improvements, and new features. I had enough time to run an Iron Bowl game between Alabama and Auburn, and then later to step into the shoes of my alma mater Jacksonville State University. What I experienced was as crunchy, as explosive, and as hard-hitting as fans would expect from college football, and the best part is that there is still more on the way.

EA Sports College Football 26 Features

After its release date reveal and then its cover star reveal, EA Sports College Football 26 confirmed a few features for the title. These include, but are definitely not limited to, all 136 FBS schools, more than 300 real-world coaches, expanded player types and abilities, the return of wear and tear, AI improvements, dynamic play-calling adjustments, dynamic substitutions, enhanced blocking/coverage systems, custom zones, a revamp stadium pulse system, 160 school-specific chants, 10 new PA tracks, and more. However, that's just scratching the surface. Fans can expect more news on Road to Glory, Dynasty, College Football Ultimate Team, and other game modes over the next few weeks.

There is no substitute for a football game, whether in-person at the stadium or seated with friends and family who are screaming Roll Tide or War Eagle at one another, but EA Sports College Football 26 is an impressive attempt at it. It genuinely felt explosive, it felt authentic, and it achieved everything developers told me it would—at least in my short time with it. "Presentation is gameplay, and gameplay is presentation," creative director Scott O'Gallagher told me. And on that point, it delivered. It didn't just feel like a real-world college football game when making a pass, attempting a run, or scoring a touchdown, but every moment leading into the game, half-time, the end, and everything in between was presented like a real-world college football broadcast. Even more than that, every quality of life improvement mattered. Many of the wrinkles in EA Sports College Football 25 have been ironed out of CFB 26 , locking in players in the moment-to-moment action.

Ultimately, I think my time with the game with EA Sports College Football 26 can be summarized with two thoughts. First, I am typically pretty slow to pick up annualized games like Madden NFL , typically waiting a few months before picking up another yearly title. After playing EA Sports College Football 26 , however, I'm not quite sure I can go back to CFB 25 . Secondly, I don't think many fans are going to be disappointed as news rolls out ahead of EA Sports College Football 26 's release in July.

6 Images
6 Images

item.title: June 17 is Going to Be a Big Day for Xbox Game Pass
item.description:
Summary

  • Xbox Game Pass Ultimate sees new games in June, including day one releases.
  • June 17 is so far the only day with not one, but two day one releases.
  • FBC: Firebreak and Lost in Random: The Eternal Die are both coming to Game Pass that day.

There are all kinds of new games coming to the Ultimate tier of Xbox Game Pass in June 2025, with two day one releases launching on the same day, June 17. The Xbox Game Pass June 2025 lineup is starting to fill up, with subscribers able to look forward to day one releases and the addition of older, but still quality, games.

On June 3, Xbox Game Pass subscribers will be treated to Metroidvania Crypt Custodian and platformer Symphonia . Then, on June 10, the Space Marine remaster will join Xbox Game Pass Ultimate as a day one release. The Space Marine remaster will be followed by the unique survival game The Alters on June 13. What makes this lineup especially impressive is that Xbox hasn't even announced all the new games coming to Game Pass in the first half of June yet, so subscribers should have even more to look forward to in the near future.

One day that Xbox Game Pass subscribers will definitely want to circle on their calendars is June 17. On that day, not one, but two promising day one releases will be added to the Ultimate tier, with subscribers able to play both FBC: Firebreak and Lost in Random: The Eternal Die . FBC: Firebreak is a co-op FPS set in the Control universe and made by the acclaimed Remedy Entertainment, while Lost in Random: The Eternal Die is a roguelike action-adventure game. Both games look great, and while their quality has yet to be determined, they both seem like solid additions to the Game Pass Ultimate lineup.

New Xbox Game Pass Games Coming in June 2025

  • Crypt Custodian - June 3
  • Symphonia - June 3
  • Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine - Master Crafted Edition - June 10
  • The Alters - June 13
  • FBC: Firebreak - June 17
  • Lost in Random: The Eternal Die - June 17
  • Rematch - June 19
  • Against the Storm - June 26

Having two day one releases on the same day makes June 17 an exciting day for Game Pass Ultimate subscribers, but there is even more to look forward to before the month is out. On June 19, the multiplayer soccer game Rematch , from the creators of Sifu , will join the Game Pass Ultimate tier. Then, on June 26, Game Pass subscribers can play the console version of the critically-acclaimed city-builder game Against the Storm . All kinds of genres are being represented by Xbox Game Pass in June, and so players should have no problem finding something that appeals to them this month.

June 17 is undoubtedly going to be a big day for Xbox Game Pass, but there's another day that subscribers will want to keep an eye on this month. The Xbox Games Showcase will take place on June 8 and is sure to be full of exciting new Game Pass announcements. Much has been said about the hot streak that Xbox Game Pass has been on lately, and all signs point to that momentum continuing in June and throughout the summer.
